Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy,

Tom Warren of The Verge said that although Windows 8's emphasis on touch computing was significant and risked alienating desktop users, a "tablet PC with Windows 8 makes an iPad feel immediately out of date" due to the capabilities of the operating system's hybrid model and increased focus on cloud services. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. An adolescent 's environment plays a huge role in their identity development . While most adolescent studies are conducted on white , middle class children , studies show that the differences begin to show up from early on . Some social factors and their impact on adolescents development and well being are : ( a ) Gender : girls differ from boys in many ways and in adolescence , girls often face specific challenges that boys do not . Females , because of their anatomy , are subject to a more rapid onset of puberty , and girls do not need as much time to reach their growth spurt . ( b ) Ethnicity : race , religion , and ethnicity have long been recognized as the chief determin ants of how adolescents experience their social world . In practice , not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match . Usually the referee not only has better judgement in this instance however , they also have a better understanding of how to control the match ( more on this later ) . In other words , they have the best of all possible worlds : they know the rules but are not obligated to follow them . This is the biggest problem when people talk about bad referee decisions . There are two reasons for the referee not to stop the match : 1 . They already know they will not . They have no interest in enforcing the rules and they usually have the final word . This is why they have such a big role in the match . Without this power they would have to stop all sorts of matches and the match referee is the one who decides when to stop a match

Mammalian hair , also known as pelage , can vary in color between populations , organisms within a population , and even on the individual organism . Light-dark color variation can be due to differences in the way an organism produces a pigment called melan in or to variations in a population as a whole . In addition to melan in in the skin , hair contains melanin , which when produced is responsible for pigment-producing biological functions . The pigment melan in , named for the melanosome , or cell that produces it , can be found either in the skin or in hair , which can be either eumelanin , derived from melanocytes , or pheom elanin , derived from melanophores . Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology , particularly with the stress systems . This is important because emotions are related to all aspects of one 's well-being , as long as they are not harmful . He believes in it as an eternal transcendent principle that makes life and morality possible ( p 9 21 ) . The moral law is the way in which the being of beings in relation to each other is expressed in themselves and in the world ( p 8 , 21 ) . [ disputed – discuss ] The Assyrian Empire became known as the Assyrian Kingdom . In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC , attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe , discovered in Vashtëmi , southeastern Albania . These initial settlements in the region were dominated by small and medium sized communities and were dominated by livestock husbandry . Agriculture in these early settlements resulted in an initial increase in size and productivity , but by the 4th millennium BC this situation began to change , agricultural societies developed in Central , Eastern and Western Europe , characterized by agricultural intensification , increased yields of cereals , cattle and sheep , and decreased food and fiber production per head of population . By the 3rd millennium BC and the 4 th millennium BC , the populations living in these farming communities had significantly improved their agricultural practices , they were much better prepared to respond to climate change . Agricultural expansion continued until the 7 th millennium BC . By the end of the last Ice Age approximately 15 % of the European land area

Knowledge , for Popper , was objective , both in the sense that it is objectively true ( or truthlike ) , and also in the sense that knowledge has a certain invariant form , and can be considered as an attribute possessed by the object of knowledge in all but one situation : knowledge is invari ant when the object , which possesses knowledge , does not act in a way which modifies the knowledge the object possesses , or in other words , does not act through a process of cognition . This invariant form is required by the concept of object ivity ; i.e . for knowledge to be considered as objective , an experience must be capable of being objectively true regardless , and indeed must be capable of being objectively known since being true and know- led is equivalent . The invariant mode of object ivity for knowledge is the mode of object ivity of the object of knowledge , namely the object of cognition , or , if knowledge is defined as knowledge

Throughout the 14th century , French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility . They ran into difficulties when attempting to do this in part because each noble was independently rich and powerful and therefore , while united in their opposition to royal power , they were incapable of preventing its expansion . The aristocracy developed a network of local bar ons , the royal court was divided , and there was no central power with the authority to force through large-scale reforms . When Edward V seized control of the kingdom after the assassination of his brother Richard in May of 1471 , this situation was exacerbated until the boy king and his younger brother died fighting against rebel forces in June . The king had been crowned two months previously and his mother Margaret Tudor ( née Beaufort in a marriage arranged over a dispute about royal succession ) had raised her sons as her own and was their guardian . The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma . During the early Jurassic , the supercontinent Pangaea broke up into the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercontinent Aval onia . Laurasia later drifted northward before forming the eastern U.S . continent and forming a land bridge between continental Euras ia and the Americas ( Stirling et al . 1998 ) . The most notable event during this period was the K–Pg –M ( KT – Ma ) extinction event during the Cretaceous Period ( KT – 104 Ma ) , which produced the Cenomanian , Cretaceous–T ertiary ( 104 Ma – 66 Ma ) , and Cretaceous– Paleogene ( 66 Ma – 0 Ma ) eras . The K– Pg extinction event eliminated the nonavian dinosaurs through a combination of changes in their habitats and large scale extinction of the cl ades of species within those habitats ( Nesb itt et al . 2001 ) . Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood ; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals . As a result they breathe half as much oxygen per minute even while they are at rest as a mammal would . When a bird has to start to take a breath , it uses its lungs to inflate its g izzard and swallow the air . In one second the bird has re- formed its air passages into hollow chambers at the bottom of its lungs . These air chambers expand in the gizzard where they are re- mixed by the muscular walls until the bird can take a breath . The bird takes a very long time to breathe in because of its gizzard ‘ s thick , high density walls . Vladimir had been prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972 . He was forced to flee to Scandinavia in 976 after his half-brother Yaropolk had murdered his father . Vladimir later settled in Constantinople and married into the Byzantine nobility . He lived until his death in 1022 at which time he was given the title of k han ( king ) of Russia , the title which , at his death , still remained . He is widely regarded as the founder of Rus ' s national consciousness and the first king of Rus ' s kingdom . He is revered as one of the greatest kings in Russian history and was crowned the first Tsar of all Russia ( ) on 21 August 862 by the Patriarch of Constantinople Heraclius . His reign lasted seven years following , during which he greatly improved standards of economic organization , cultural development and warfare . Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are in a constant search for the real essence of themselves , their sense of who they are , what they need ( their sense of self ) and then how they will live ( their sense of purpose and destiny ) . This stage continues up until the time they reach adulthood . In some of the most extreme cases , adolescents have a deep desire to die . The concept of identity means many things to different people ; it can mean the development of one 's sense of identity as a person , or the development of one ' s sense of purpose and destiny in life ; it can mean the development of one 's personality , or the development of a sense of selfhood . Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician , Gregorio Marañón , who injected patients with epinephrine and subsequently asked them how they felt . The answer he received from a number of patients who could not take epine phrine was , “ very , very , very , ” with increasing intensity , or “ to the point of death ” , depending on the symptoms . This condition , known as hemodynamic shock , was noted by the Spanish physicians and is still part of the medical lexicon to this day . Schach ter proposed that by causing a decrease in cerebral blood flow , epinephrine would cause patients to become dizzy and nauseated . They would lose control during a heart attack and subsequently die . When the patients returned to normal , the patients ' blood vessels would have reopened and ep inephrine would have the same negative effect . Like the reptiles , birds are primarily uricotelic , that is , their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or urea salts . This is particularly evident in many reptiles like snakes , turtles and lizards . This is why they excrete as much salt in their bodies as urea ( uric acid , ur ic salts , and ur ic acid salts ) and why it takes more food to maintain their size ( because it is easy to burn excess calories and energy ) than to build their bodies . But some of the mammals are also ur icotelic , but some other reptiles do eat protein-rich food like the carnivorous birds . There are many arguments about whether birds are either uricic or uricotel ic . When Nintendo released the NES in the US , the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles . Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those of rivals with the same idea in mind . This meant that the NES had more stylized elements in its logo than did , for instance , the rival Super Nintendo Entertainment System . This difference led some to suspect that , had this styling not been intentional , the graphics were simply more advanced because the system was using a completely different hardware architecture [ 20 ] However , even with the addition of these more advanced components , the NES still had only 2 megabytes of RAM . Some of these philosophers have even suggested that we have a particular duty to learn from the past , given the possibility that future events might be worse than our ancestors ' worst fears . Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values . In addition to the dollar the coinage act officially established monetary units of the U.S . These monetary units of the U.S. include the penny , the dime , the quarter , the half dollar , and the dollar as a whole . All of these monetary units share the same unit of value , regardless of the specific sizes of the coins in circulation . In order for these coins to fit their respective niches in circulation the design of each coin needed to be as durable as possible . By this the American coinage act wanted that all U .S . coins would be interchangeable across the continent . This act of interchangeable currencies and denominations was intended to keep the U.S. dollar as a unit of value stable in terms of the exchange value of all coins across the continent . Many modern specialty matches have been devised , with unique winning conditions . The most common of these is the ladder match . In the basic ladder match , the winning team is required to earn the best of three falls before the match is decided to the point of no return . In a standard game , there are two wrestlers in each team , and their objective is to gain more victories than their opponent during the match . Winning with a technical fall allows one team to gain more points than their opponent . A victory by pin allows one to score more points , since the wrestler in control or position by the act of the referee on the wrestler on top . The final scoring method is the knockout , which gives the wrestler with the most victories from the top to the end of a fall . A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing . Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way , most prey species are safe from predators at least long enough to reproduce ( even if being able to breed is n't necessarily a sign a species is in danger ) . A true predator never harms its prey but kills it . The difference is in whether the animal acts against the purpose of the predator or not . In order to be a predator , the animals must be able to detect the presence of a potential predator . In order to kill and feed on another living thing , the predator must either see that the other animal poses a threat to itself or use hunting equipment to locate and kill an animal that could harm itself . Predators that act against their purpose do not kill any living thing . They simply kill a carcass or piece of an animal .

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem . Self-esteem is defined as one 's thoughts and feelings about one 's self-concept and identity . Most theories on self-esteem define self-esteem around three categories : a ) physical competence b ) social competence c ) cognitive competence . They have developed three dimensions of self-esteem : personal competence , e . g. self- satisfaction with one 's appearance , abilities , and personality ; social competence , e. g , liking of oneself , feelings towards one 's family , friends or community ; cognitive competence , e .g . self- regard , regard towards one 's own abilities , personality , and potential , and self-efficacy . These factors are more interrelated than people think . For instance , if a person is physically fit , he or she is also feeling good about their self-esteem . On the other hand , somebody who is self-dep recating and lacking in cognitive competence may also feel the same towards him or herself . On the other

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century , with compositions by Josquin des Prez . The early a cappella polyphonies were a combination of four and five voices . From 1735 to 17 55 a French polyphony , known as the or atorio polyphonic style , consisted of four , five , and six parts , but the latter had no fixed parts ; the part numbering was determined by the conductor rather than the composer . Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment , it is not the case . The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and we simply do n't have the tools required for a systematic analysis of such processes . However , the idea of memory being an information storing mechanism has been widely used in the literature . However , what happens when different parts of the same neural network activate at different times ? If each memory component operates on its own temporal window of activation , this would seem to represent different memory episodes . The answer is no – instead all memory components operate on the same time horizon , the temporal distribution of activation of the neurons comprising the memory circuit . A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels ( e.g. , anger , pride , fear , etc . ) as well as the emotions themselves . Such an approach has led to an increasingly complex understanding of human emotions . What is the value of taking these conceptual changes into account in the teaching of human development ? In the present contribution , I examine the implications of the cultural account of emotion for the intergenerational transmission of affective behaviour towards strangers , using data from the United States , Austria , Sweden , and Australia . The results indicate that affective reactions to strangers can be mediated only partially by shared culture . The impact of culture can be observed also in cross -cultural variation . The result indicates that in many cases it is better to explain individual differences in inter -generational changes in affective reactions to strangers using culturally informed theoretical frameworks rather than via culturally informed

The United States has become essentially a two-party system . Since a conservative ( such as the Republican Party ) and liberal ( such as the Democratic Party ) party can run in almost any state or even in two states or more , two -party registration in the U.S. is almost exclusively a product of national rather than local factors . This has been especially true in the U.S.A . since 1960 . The other feature of the two -party system in the U.S.A . is to prevent any possibility of a third party developing , while keeping the Democrats and Republicans in charge . The two parties are very similar , very conservative and very liberal . The main differences are in economics and foreign policy , and those differences usually coincide with geographic and religious differences . The American Two -Party System in Brief A two- party system is usually thought to arise due to the fact that there are only two major parties in a representative legislature ( the state or lower federal government ) .

Darwin was hard at work on his `` big book '' on Natural Selection , when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace , who stayed on the island of Hons y in Singapore . The parcel included a few seeds of a species of plant Darwin had observed in the Straits Settlements and several shells with an inscription from Wallace that read : “ I am sending you a sort of shell with a few drops of juice from a plant that I know will be useful to you . I can assure you of the sincerity with which I send the shell and the substance ” . Darwin 's excitement over this gift was great because this plant provided a solution to what he must have at this stage of his research considered the fatal problem of inter specific hybridization , that is , the formation of viable hybrids between the two divergent species on the Galapagos Islands -- namely the Charles Darwin Gal apagos finches and the Andean finch

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . In contrast , a board -only organization has an entirely independent board with no authority to appoint or fire anyone and little or no control . For instance , in a membership organization , a board member could fire a fellow board member ( with cause ) . In contrast , the board - only nonprofit organization would still allow board members to fire each other , but it would be difficult to find a board member guilty of `` with cause `` because board members would have to show evidence of intent . But for many it was also a political triumph , for not only did Pompey 's army defeat a massive army commanded by the great generals of the Republic , Caesar himself , and Pompe y 's two sons , but , by defeating the two eldest of the triumvirate , Pompey effectively removed that man 's ability to command the Army of the East . It was , in effect , the final triumph , the culmination of Caesar 's triumph that had begun nearly two decades earlier when , in 69 AD , he captured the great Roman City of Jerusalem

The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire . Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as `` invasions , '' these migrations were not necessarily attempts to suppl ant the old institutions . Indeed , it may well be that the Romans , like the ancient Greeks , did not really want to replace one state with another but to establish new patterns of political rule that would not disturb the equilibrium of the ancient political mil lion with which they had become intermingled . If t his is correct , then the invasion of Christianity by Rome should not really be described as a `` conversion `` from paganism . Rather , it will be more use ful to regard the spread of the Christian faith not as the emergence of a new political -religious system but as a response to the political situation s that had arisen in the wake of the Roman conquest of the Greek -speaking world . Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease . In a microbial culture , a growth medium is provided for a specific agent . A sample taken from an external site suspected of containing an eti ologic agent may be cultured . Bacteria and yeasts will grow in laboratory media whereas fungi tend to grow only in specific media . If fungi grow in the external culture , an alternative diagnostic approach is to apply microscopic examination to any culture taken from this site . Using this approach , characteristic macrosc opic phenotypes and characteristic nucleic acids species found in the macroscopic specimen may be discovered . This method may also be employed , in conjunction with microbiological culture , to identify eti olog ic agents of disease in the external culture . These methods of sample collection and diagnosis often present challenges because microbial cultures do not always identify the etiologic agent within the sample . Furthermore , these cultures may be contaminated with bacteria and other microbials ,

While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned , Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture . Many local Carnival customs are claimed to derive directly from these church festivals . Today 's Carnival celebrations ( usually held the last two weeks in Lent ) have evolved in both Europe , and the United States . Many have retained the Latin 'Civit atis carniversibus ' ( 'give thanks to the Carnival-wors hippers ' ) , or the German 'Herren wohnern gr ünden ' ( 'men for the folk -worshippers ' ) . The English word 'carnival ' is a shortened form , since in the Middle Ages it was more often used to refer to a 'night of revels ' . C arnival is celebrated in almost every European continent , but also in North America , Africa , and the Far East . Adolescence marks a rapid change in one 's role within a family . Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully , but are unable to demonstrate much influence over family affairs . During adolescence , children begin to develop a relationship with an adult who has parental authority and responsibility to care for them . In the older years a child may be more of a leader , but in the early years he is also dependent upon the approval of or assistance from a parent . There is usually a family history of mental illness in some form . During the prenatal period , the infant often exhibits aggressive behavior , frequently to the point of injury inflicted upon the mother . It is estimated that about 20 % of all infants develop mental illness during the first year . In response to the early-to-mid-17th century `` continental rationalism '' John Locke ( 1632–1704 ) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding ( 1689 ) a very influential view wherein people can and should choose the method of political organization that best works better for them . This idea of freedom and democracy was first put forth by John Locke in his first of two Treatises on government ( 1689 , written in response to the Glorious Revolution of 1688 that replaced the monarchy of England with a parliamentary republic ) . The idea of democracy is that there should be some form of self-determination ( for example , self -rule , and self -determination ) so that people can freely choose the form of government that best suits their interests best and will have as much or as little power as they want . Racial categor ization has not become more widespread . The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals , the Soviet Union ( USSR ) and the United States ( US ) , for supremacy in space . It was the highest stage rivalry in history and is regarded by many as the most intense and protracted period of military competition during the Cold War . The race began in the early 50s with the founding of the Soviet Union as a communist state in that country , and eventually led to the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962 . The two superpowers then spent the space race focusing on other activities of more strategic and strategic interest such as space exploration and the nuclear missile race , until the late 60s . Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period , plenty of sunshine , and a moderate rainfall , usually from 600 to 1,200 mm ( 24 to 47 in ) in the dry season , from March to November , and from February to October . Water and nutrition during the dry season , however , increase resistance to pests and disease , including the cotton bug , the white mott le virus , and white rust . Mary 's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of Byzantium . Beginning with St. Augustine , theologians have generally followed his lead in viewing Mary as innocent , guiltless , and free from all sin and from all obligation to salvation . But in a much more recent and influential work of St. Thomas Aquinas , this position is rejected . Thomas is clear that Mary s condition of simplicity is not the result of original sin nor is it exempt from any taint of original sin and from any obligation to salvation . In the work to which I refer , Thomas presents this doctrine as an interpretation of the entire New Testament . This work , while not yet finished , has recently been brought into existence with the assistance of a scholar of the highest order , Mr. Richard Mc Anally . His work is the foundation upon which the rest of the work rests . I

There is usually an indication for a specific identification of an infectious agent only when such identification can aid in the treatment or prevention of the disease , or to inform family members to help prevent spread of disease . Sometimes the indication is useful for research purposes or to identify the general public and so inform them of the risks . However , sometimes the true indication for an infectious agent is not known or recognised as a disease in order that the population continues to be exposed to it in order to allow it to remain a natural phenomenon . For instance , humans may not realise that an agent is an infectious agent if no specific symptoms are evident . For this reason , the term infectious disease should not be viewed in a narrow way but rather encompass all agents that are pathogenic to humans . The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806 . In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign , Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic tactics . These tactics were to be made manifest again and again during the Nap oleonic Wars : 1 . The attack is launched from positions of high-ground which are at the same time defensible . 2 . The object of the attack is not to conquer territory but to force an adversary to resign the field before the enemy can organize his forces . 3 . The advance is to be launched from an elevated or defensible position where the enemy is in difficulty in maintaining a presence . 4 . The attack is to continue as a direct frontal assault until the point where all reserves of strength are drawn back in preparation for a retreat . With respect to these outer regions , the Qing maintained imperial control , with the emperor acting as Mongol khan , patron of Tibetan Buddhism and protector of Muslims . The Qing court thus held a privileged position , to have the emperor 's personality and authority vested in the Chinese emperor as the supreme sovereign of China . Although the Qing maintained this role of protector to East Muslims under the Qing Empire , the Ming emperor and their court continued to act as the protector of Islam in Yunnan under the banner of the Chinese state . Chinese emperor still enjoyed the Muslim people ' s loyalty and their protection . The only exception was that when the Qing began to expand its imperial territory towards the central plateau and northwest China during the second half of the eighteenth century , the court did not expand the imperial frontiers of Islam in areas that are the ancestral homeland of Muslims . This decision was made in response to the growing Chinese fear of possible Russian influence

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker based thinking , believing that it helps them form their relationship . For example , you are an exclusive thinker who thinks that the boundaries of your relationship are more important than your connection to other people . I have met and worked with some people on the path of self-improvement who have adopted this restrictive thinking . . An inclusive thought is one in which the boundaries are perceived by others to be inclusive or inclusive-exclusive . For example , a person , who is an exclusive thinker , can consider his boundaries to be inclusive or exclusive since all other people in the world are allowed an opinion of their boundaries ... Asian Americans in New York City , according to the 2010 Census , number more than one million , greater than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles and Boston . Asian Americans have been the fastest growing ethnic group and now account for 17 % of the New-York City population , an increase of 20.6 percent since 2000 . The census also estimates that between 2000 and 2010 , the Asian American population grew by 8 32,000 to reach 2.2 million , the third strongest overall among large ethnic groups in the United States . As of 2010 the population of Asian Americans is projected to continue growing at its fastest pace -about one half of one percent each year- up to 4.7 million in 2040 . These projections assume that Asian Americans maintain their growth rate of about one half of one percent per year with a projected population growth of 6.5 % . It is not clear exactly where collegiate a cappella began . The Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute ( formerly known as the RPI Glee Club ) , established in 1873 , became official in 18 75 . This organization eventually absorbed the `` Chorus Society `` of Troy University , and the National Association of Amateur Musical Societies . The National Association of Colleges Amateurs , which began in 1924 in Boston , eventually grew to approximately one thousand collegiate a ca ppella organizations . Most other notable collegiate a ca ppella organizations are located in the United States . The United States Collegiate A cappella Federation ( USCAF ) is the official national association for collegiate a cappella . It is sponsored by the National Association of Colleg iate a cappella Societies ( NAC AS ) , the National Association of College and University P lyfying ( N AC UPC ) and the American Society of Compos ers , Authors and Publishers ( ASCAP ) . Nanjing , one of the nation 's most important cities for over a thousand years , is recognized as one of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China , and the headquarters of the Imperial Household Department within the Imperial Palace . Nanjing is also known as the City of Nine Hundred Canals , or the City of the Narrows and Water-Walls . The capital for many years after its founding in 221 BC , Nan jing was a flourishing civilization . In the Tang dynasty , it reached a high cultural-political -military level , and was once home , together with the capitals of H anoi , Chengtu , Xianyang , Jinan , Yanjing , Xi'an , and Xi'an- Fu , to the largest number of generals in history . Today , the number of generals is below that of kings and emperors , but is still sufficient for a military dictator to have multiple generals at each position of his cabinet and to oversee the construction of a multitude of military camps and fortresses .

Before the early 20th century , treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore . Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections were described over 1500 years ago . In 1770 , Robert Ramboll discovered an effect of an herbal remedy , in which it killed a disease-causing bacteria . Ramboll and his colleagues referred to this herbal remedy as a `` vulnerary `` , and they named it after it . A major effect of the plant is reducing inflammation . A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each , known as halves . Each half runs continuously , meaning that the clock is not stopped whilst the game is in play . The referee calls the clock after each goal scored , and when a player is injured or goes off injured , so as to avoid lengthy stoppages . At the end of the match , each half finishes , unless a penalty or a free-kick is scored to restart the game to a new end -of-phase ( or `` period `` ) . A game is stopped before any of these events happen , so that play will be resumed from the start of the next `` period `` . The referee will typically allow a goal or a card throw or kick to restart a game , provided that it was within the bounds of the legal requirements within the rule set of an official football match . Hiberni ( Ireland ) , Pictish ( northern Britain ) and Britons ( southern Britain ) tribes , all speaking Insular Celtic , inhabited the islands at the beginning of the first millennium AD . They were originally closely related to the Irish , but the two peoples did not exchange any genealogical information . Subsequent inter breeding between the two peoples developed an independent Celtic branch which split off from Pict ish Celtic in late La Tène Iron Age , the Celtic branch also called the Insular / Insular Celtic . Irish historians refer to the Celtic branch as the `` Proto Irish '' and the Celtic branch as the Insular Celtic . The Irish share a complex history with the Pictish . Both groups originated from a common Proto-C eltic culture , but Irish and Pictish culture have undergone many cultural changes since the end of the first millennium AD . The vast Seleucid Empire was , like Egypt , mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite . The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced by Greek mercenaries from their homeland , which formed a second elite . Both in power and in the common pool of manpower , the Seleucids and Ptolemies provided a counterbalance to local elite dominance . Both countries were based around their capital city which remained a major cultural melting pot , despite the various ethnicities within that melting pot . The Seleucid and Ptolemaic dynasties maintained a constant balance between local elite members and members of the Greek elite within their kingdom . By the time of Alexander , the main centres of power within the Seleucid state were Alexandria and Alexandria . By 325 BC , the Ptolema ic dynasties were being challenged by the Se leucid king , Ptolemy II Auletes , who set his sights on the capital Alexandria . Pto lemy II 's strategy revolved around seizing the city by surprise .

“ The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature. ” Literature in all its forms can be seen as written records , some are more or less explicit , but all have a power over us that is hard to overestimate . It also remains largely untranslated .

Ideas for affirmative action came as early as the Reconstruction Era ( 1865-1877 ) in which a former slave population lacked the skills and resources for sustainable living . In the southern states of the US , the new generation of white southerners that included some returning plan ters and their families that included more than a few freed slaves sought to change history by using race , class and gender-specific quotas to achieve some level of equality amongst all peoples in order to make the new republic a more attractive destination for newcomers and investors . In the long term the system became so successful ( with various levels of success still present in some states as recently as the 21st century ) that it became a global model used to increase the quality of educational opportunities for disadvantaged groups . However in the short term the quotas were resented by those in power and they were used against both black southerners and other minorities as a way of keeping black communities out .

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen , potentially damaging ( e.g. , mutation causing ) compounds known as free radicals can form . Most of these are oxidizers ( i.e. , oxygen radicals ) while others are electron acceptors ( e.g . , a variety of metals ) . These compounds are either present in a higher or in a lower concentration depending on factors such as the cellular metabolic activity and physiological state of the organism . It is therefore important for cells to protect themselves from these compounds . As a result , antioxidants have been classified into different groups according to their roles in different stages of oxidation process in a cell . In a living cell , several antioxidants exist in the antioxidant environment . They are involved in neutral ization of free radicals/ oxidants . The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s , for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements in a meaningful language because of the nature of physical objects itself . In other words , the notion of truth in scientific thought had become impossible without the aid of language . The idea that language could serve as a model of truth , a model that could predict in advance the results of experiments , seemed to be as much a contradiction as a dog predicting that he will run back and forth along the same path . Thus the phenomenalists were forced to leave their former positions in the face of their failure . If there is anything the post- Humean empiric ists were united against , it was this attempt to make sense of our everyday language that is so often criticized as a dogmatic and unrealistic enterprise . One bird predator may take a bird or even two birds from another predator , and in the end both have been hunted down . As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms , the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century . The Roman Empire eventually spread into the Mediterranean and Western Europe , gradually incorporating its wealth and politics while its citizens made important strides in the arts , science , and culture . Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials . They were closely modeled after the mosaics of the Roman Empire . A number of them include scenes of battles and events in the lives of Mohammed , the last prophet of Islam . There are also panels of poems by the Prophet Muhammad which are painted onto the tiles . As af Ali Khan 's pupil , Muhamm edin Ali began producing the first large scale Islamic tiles in the Indian style , while other artists were working on an independent but similar line . Later it was the Indian craftsmen who were the first to work the non-Islamic patterns which are now used in most mosques today . Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record . It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years . Copper also occurs in a large number of other forms . If you want to grow a great array of interesting varieties that are perfect for your garden use at least 3 lbs of copper sulphate ( sul phate in other formulas ) when first moistening your seed or planting soil , then replace it with about 4 qts every 5 days . Different phases of digestion take place including : the cephalic phase , gastric phase , and intestinal phase . The cephalic phase occurs at the sight , thought and smell , whilst the gastric phase occurs in the stomach . In the intestinal phase , digested food is digested from the stomach to the small intestine . In the small intestine , in the ileum , food is chewed till it is used up . In the bowel movements , water and mucous particles are released . In the large intestine , the stool is digested . In order to be digested , a food must undergo stages such as hydrolysis , lysis , and protein digestion , before finally being broken down into the various nutrients that we need . Digestion is more complicated than you may have thought . Let ’ s take a glimpse into how this process works by taking a closer look at digestion . The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s . Species are increasingly being moved by humans ( on purpose and accidentally ) , or because of climate change . The more species we bring in , the more we 're likely to spread diseases and cause major ecological and economic changes . As we move species around , this can lead to their dispersal , with consequent consequences on other species . In many parts of the world - including eastern Africa , Madagascar , and southern Asia - many species are still becoming invasive where they entered recently . And because animals are so diverse and have a huge number of genetic variations , we could have a really significant problem on our hands , but the scientific data has n't caught up with our understanding of species inv asions and dispersal . In the spring of 1800 , Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy , aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when Napoleon surrendered in June 1815 . Although the battle that ensued from these crossing marked the high mark of the War of the Grand Alliance , it seemed to many as though Napoleon had missed his moment of greatness . He could not hold on to the territories he had conquered in India because of the British , so he moved his army south into Italy and captured the town of Verona . The English forces , who had occupied Verona on behalf of Napoleon , had no intention of surrendering . With this strategic disaster for the French in sight , Napoleon prepared to leave Ver ona . The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity , in the vernacular , and with the entertainment of readers in mind , was Bernard Le Bovier de la Tour-Voy age ( 1621 ) , a French doctor and lay man who published a series of short works entitled Hist ories of Things Seen and heard . In these works , to a level of sophistication that would be highly unusual from 1500 to 1650 , Le Bovier addressed his readers in the first person , expressing scientific ideas that they could understand and making them available for their private enjoyment . Some street trams ( streetcars ) used conduit third-rail current collection . The third rail was below street level . The tram picked up the current through a plough ( not a tube ) . The third rail conductors in both types used to sit on an electric wire for insulation Street tram conductors used to wear gloves . The third rail ( the `` high voltage bus -line power supply line or `` overhead power line `` `` ) was an overhead electric current conduit . Current was conducted to ground the vehicle through the system . The street current collector was a three wire conductor consisting of a single conductor on top and two other conductors in the bottom of the gutter . Conductors above street level were insulated as above . Street current collectors needed to have a grounding conductor between the wire and the ground . This grounding conductor could have a single or a three wire conductor in order to establish a path of least action in ground fault circuit interrupters

In 633 AD , Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD , largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam . By the 12th century , Iran had turned into the world 's largest Muslim state . The Iranian monarchy at that time was Sunni Muslim . The Iran of the 19th century was still dominated by Sunni Muslim rulers and the Iranian aristocracy was still Sunni Muslim . Iran has an indigenous Sunni Muslim culture , with a strong Sufi tradition dating back to the 9 th century . But the modern Shiite rulers , particularly the Pahlavis dynasty , adopted the modern Islamic State religion of Sunni Islam . What is more , the Shiite Ayatollah Khome ini had been among the Sunni leaders of Iran . Following the unveiling of Windows 8 , Microsoft faced criticism ( particularly from free software supporters ) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have secure boot disabled . Microsoft responded by saying users could always boot to trusted ( signed ) Windows 8 media via optical drive . The most comprehensive solution is to use secure boot-aware firmware ( SB-FAT ) to run unsigned ( trusted ) OSes . Microsoft did not allow the use of hardware-assisted secure boot , however , because it requires OEMs to install their firmware-specific extensions , making it difficult for end-users to use Windows to boot off of the local hard drive . A team of researchers from the University of Manchester has recently introduced a new method for doing just that . To accomplish this , the researchers turned to a little known Windows mechanism called Secure Boot that is capable of running unsigned drivers ( unsigned code ) when used exclusively , and requires a physical access to the device for the OS

By 1959 , American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space , because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury and Gemini missions . ( Some of those Gemini flights were actually planned as Mercury flybys ) . The first manned mission to outer space would be called a `` crisis test flight '' ; this first human spaceflight would be necessary to prepare for and build up the space program , to build toward the actual launching of human missions ( or Apollo flights ) . In order to make a first manned space flight seem to be a big event for public attention , President Eisenhower had promised in his Inaugural Address ( on March 9 , 1953 – which mentioned his plan to send a man to the moon as a `` project for new friends , a project for advancing our own cause , a project for old and new allies `` ) to announce such a flight once the Gemini program had proved

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 ( 47 sq mi ) , and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin ( the main sources are Mount Batt enberg and Mount Reh oboth ) . There are four major towns and settlements : The Island Town , Saint Helena Town , The Castle Town , and the Grand Camp . The town of King 's Town was evacuated after an earthquake on June 6 , 1980 . The town of Port Louis was abandoned after an earthquake on September 6 , 1991 . The two inhabited valleys of Mount Re h oboth and St . George do not have communications with Port Louis . The two inhabited valleys of Saint Helena have no communications with Port Louis . The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841 . In 1843 the possibility of war with Mexico over the Texas war with the United States was raised . It was after that that things went bad for Texas . The border dispute was brought to the front by Secretary of the Treasury Salmon P. Chase who felt that Texas was trying to acquire too much power for its size . He had come from California to Texas to deal with the problem . President Chase said if no more territorial acquisitions were granted to Texas and Washington , they would consider the situation a violation of the United States charter . Following the negotiations and the negotiations of the Mexican government Chase left Texas at large . The American government , who did not want another war to be started , made peace with Mexico . However , it meant the annexation of Texas . Texas did not accept the annexation

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has been employed in the study of zoology to enhance the quality of available animals \ [ [ @ CR1 ] ] . It is , in other words , * a practice which has been known for many thousands of years , with the earliest evidence of crossbreeding in Europe being found in the Neolithic and Iron Age . '' [ @ 2 ] . However , despite all the evidence to prove the practice , the practice is still relatively unknown to society . This is possibly because of the inherent risk to other animals involved . Nevertheless , the practice of captive breeding is an ancient one . One can speculate as to why the practice was started , and it is the purpose of this article to study that question . The practice is an important area for the protection of endangered animals

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment , including Deism and talk of atheism . Deism , according to Thomas Paine , is the simple belief that the entire Christian God is a divine idea formed by all human minds , as opposed to the belief that the Christian God is a particular individual or individual deity . Another idea , developed with the Enlightenment and then abandoned , is the idea that religion or the supernatural does not exist in reality ( this became important during the Second World War . However , deism survives as an independent academic discipline . The word itself , deriving from the Latin deus , does not appear in the Bible ; , it refers to a deity in the absence of an explicit reference , an idea that can also be found in ancient Greek , though this use of deism and /or agnost icism is not clear or common . Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the Engadine Valley to the north , and the Engadine Hills to the east . The mountains which can be found in Switzerland constitute three main categories : the Alps , the Bernese Alps and the Berner Alp , which makes the most extensive series of mountains in Europe , including the Alps , the highest in the world , in South America , and is one of the eight highest in the world . The mountains of Switzerland have their own distinct character , but some typical characteristics of the country as a whole can also be noted : they are well- defined with distinct peaks and ridges ; their slopes are generally relatively smooth ; their summits are often very steep ; and their glaciers extend far towards , and above , the valley floor . Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence , and using the −3 °C ( 27 °F ) coldest month ( January ) isotherm , the city lies within the coldest temperature category in the western USA . Boston residents spend roughly 9 % of their lifetime outside , with a population of approximately 575 000 . From January to March Boston is generally considered to be the most moderate winter climate . It is common in Boston to find snow on a few consecutive days at any point during the entire winter , although this occurs most frequently during the snowiest seasons ( November – February ) . From May through September , it is the coldest year with a winter mean average temperature of 5 °C ( 42 °F ) . From October 1st to April 30th Boston averages a temperature of 3 °C ( 39 °F ) . Boston is located in the northeastern USA , approximately 200 miles ( 320 km ) southeast of Washington , DC .

As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as well as Islam , were a kind of gift to humanity , like the Torah and the Gospel before it , was held by a handful of Islamic scholars , like Rumi , Ibn Warraq , Muhammad I qbal , and Ahmad ibn Hanbal . By the time of the French Revolution , where Muslims were treated as the only possible `` other , '' in terms of a political alliance , there were few madras as where such thinkers like Ibn Khaldoun were actively involved in Islamic political and social life . But many had been involved either through collaboration , through political connections or by taking up different religious , intellectual or political roles .
